brief_summary.textblock:
Undernutrition and growth restriction due to poor diet and inadequate nutrient intake
      continues to be a global challenge, particularly in the developing countries including
      Uganda. The etiology of inadequate nutrient supply to infants may relate to lack of
      resources or knowledge or a combination of both. Poor nutrient intake and impaired growth
      may affect brain and cognitive development.

      This study aims to evaluate nutrient intake, growth and cognitive function among children
      between 6 and 36 months living in the fertile Kabale and Kisoro region in south-western
      Uganda.  The investigators hypothesize that nutrition education to mothers can bring about
      improved dietary intake and nutritional status among children aged 6-36 months.

clinical_study.brief_title: Improving the Nutrition Status of Infants in South-Western Uganda

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  A lead caretaker with a   6-8 months infant (child/lead caretaker pair) who will have
             given consent to participate in the study. If there is more than one child of the age
             in the household, the younger one will be taken as the index/study child.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Is older than 8 months at baseline

          -  Congenital malformations or physical handicap that may influence growth or interfere
             with taking of anthropometric measurements

          -  Disability that will influence nutrient intake

          -  Been diagnosed with mental or brain illness as evidenced by mother or health worker.

          -  If the family that is likely to emigrate during the study period

clinical_study.official_title: Improving the Nutrition Status of 6 to 8 Months Old Children Through Diet Diversification and Better Dietary Intakes in the Kabale and Kisoro Districts in South-Western Uganda

oversight_info.authority: Uganda: Regional Committees for Medical and Health Research Ethics

primary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in stunting between the three indicated time points.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in the prevalence of stunting (<-2 SD of the WHO, 2006 growth reference standards)

primary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in Bayley Mental Development Index between the three indicated time periods.
primary_outcome.measure: Change in the Bayley Mental Development Index

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in mean weight for age z-score between the three indicated time periods.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in mean weight for age z-score

secondary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in mean weight for height z-score between the three indicated time periods.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in mean weight for height z-score

secondary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in MUAC between the three indicated time periods.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in mean Mid Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC)

secondary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in DDS between the three indicated time periods.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in mean diet diversification score (DDS)

secondary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in ASS between the three indicated time periods.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Ages and Stages Questionnaire Scores (ASS)

secondary_outcome.description: We will measure the change in Bayley Child Development test 3 ed. between the three indicated time periods.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Bayley Child Development test 3 ed.

secondary_outcome.description: Fecal samples will be collected and we will measure the change in gut microbiota between the three indicated time periods.
We will measure the change in KABC between the two groups after 36 months.
secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children (KABC)

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention
